title: How to Make Jerk Pork

steps.headline: Rub the seasoning into the pork shoulder.
steps.description: Leave for the pork shoulder for a minimum of 1/2 an hour (several hours is better).

steps.headline: Rub on the jerk marinade and leave it on the pork shoulder for at least 5 hours (overnight is recommended).
steps.description: The longer you leave it, the more the seasoning and flavour will penetrate the meat. Make sure you store it in the refrigerator in a well sealed container.

steps.headline: The next morning, prepare a grill at a low temperature and barbecue the pork shoulder until it's nice and tender.
steps.description: This process can take many hours. If your pork has a layer of fat on it (which it should, for best taste), make sure to keep the fat on the TOP, not touching the grill. If you keep it on the grill, all the juice will fall out, and not into the meat. You can also use the indirect heat method of cooking. Heat one side of the grill, and keep the meat on the opposite side.

steps.headline: Allow your roast to rest for 5-10 minutes before cutting.
steps.description: This allows the meat to firm slightly, and retain it's tenderness. Chop the pork shoulder into bite size pieces when it is ready to serve. You can catch the drippings of the meat in a small pan and use it to make gravy for your meal. (While your meat is resting, in a small frying pan, start sauteing some diced onions with a small amount of cooking oil. When they start to brown, add your drippings from the roast. Allow the mixture to get hot. While this is going on, mix together 2 tbsp of all purpose flour with cold water, and mix well, until no lumps are in the mixture. Slowly add flour and water to your gravy until desired thickness is achieved. Allow gravy to cook for 5 minutes to that the flour taste is cooked out. You can add some of your left-over jerk seasoning to the gravy while it's cooking, for an extra hit of flavour).

steps.headline: Feel free to serve it with hard dough bread, festival, fried dumplings, rice and peas, boiled yams and plantain, etc.
steps.description: Google is your friend when it comes to sides to serve with this.

Rub on the jerk marinade and leave it on the pork shoulder for at least 5 hours (overnight is recommended). The longer you leave it, the more the seasoning and flavour will penetrate the meat. Make sure you store it in the refrigerator in a well sealed container. The next morning, prepare a grill at a low temperature and barbecue the pork shoulder until it's nice and tender. This process can take many hours. If your pork has a layer of fat on it (which it should, for best taste), make sure to keep the fat on the TOP, not touching the grill. If you keep it on the grill, all the juice will fall out, and not into the meat. You can also use the indirect heat method of cooking. Heat one side of the grill, and keep the meat on the opposite side. Allow your roast to rest for 5-10 minutes before cutting. This allows the meat to firm slightly, and retain it's tenderness. Chop the pork shoulder into bite size pieces when it is ready to serve. You can catch the drippings of the meat in a small pan and use it to make gravy for your meal. (While your meat is resting, in a small frying pan, start sauteing some diced onions with a small amount of cooking oil. When they start to brown, add your drippings from the roast. Allow the mixture to get hot. While this is going on, mix together 2 tbsp of all purpose flour with cold water, and mix well, until no lumps are in the mixture. Slowly add flour and water to your gravy until desired thickness is achieved. Allow gravy to cook for 5 minutes to that the flour taste is cooked out. You can add some of your left-over jerk seasoning to the gravy while it's cooking, for an extra hit of flavour). Feel free to serve it with hard dough bread, festival, fried dumplings, rice and peas, boiled yams and plantain, etc. Google is your friend when it comes to sides to serve with this.
